Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 04:28PM - edited Apr 7, 2009 04:47PM by Brenda_R No, mine wasn't in muscle. It was under the breastbone, right next to my aorta. Lol I guess your facility bone scan id different from mine. The screen above me showed only shades of gray and white. Maybe the tech's screen had color but I was faced away from it.  I'd still want to talk to an oncologist. Let know what you do.  added- maybe the best way is to show you. here's 2 images from the ct part of my original scan. http://i49.photobucket.com/albums/f272/ladypcer/tumorandnode.jpg http://i49.photobucket.com/albums/f272/ladypcer/node.jpg Keep in mind that these are all gone now.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 06:44AM - edited Apr 7, 2009 06:46AM by Brenda_R From the BCO website- Stage IIIA describes invasive breast cancer in which either: My Onc also said I was stage 3. Also- this is from the SSD website, although it doesn't give a stage- 13.10 Breast (except sarcoma-13.04) (See 13.00K4.) A. Locally advanced carcinoma (inflammatory carcinoma, tumor of any size with direct extension to the chest wall or skin, tumor of any size with metastases to the ipsilateral internal mammary nodes.
Posts.Title: Am I stage II or Stage III jeanjean_chang nelia48

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 07:12AM Brenda_R wrote: Barbe, no they aren't the same.  But the site says- "or cancer may have spread to lymph nodes near the breastbone"  That's localy advanced and that's stage3. The best thing any of you can do is ask your Onc what your stage is. But I have to say that Stage 3 doesn't mean you're doomed. There's lots of us Stage 3 gals that are alive and kicking, and NED.  I don't feel any more at risk than a stage 1 dx. In fact I feel that being stage 3 means you get hit with the max treatment and have no more or less chance of recurring than ealier stages.
Posts.Title: Am I stage II or Stage III jeanjean_chang nelia48

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 08:50AM Brenda_R wrote: http://www.bccancer.bc.ca/HPI/Nursing/Education/breastcancer/breasthealthbasics.htm Table 2 shows inframammary node chain. Where the F is located is where my +IM node was. Bone scan doesn't light up but shows darker areas where activity is going on. Pet scan lights up and mine showed hot spots in the spine, hip, pelvis and shoulder. They were false positives, and why I was originaly dx'ed as stage 4. But it also lit up the tumor and IM node, and those had higher SUV values. The positive IM node also showed up on the ct as an enlarged node.  After treatment a follow up pet/ct showed that the node had dissapeared.
Posts.Title: Am I stage II or Stage III jeanjean_chang nelia48

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 01:36PM Brenda_R wrote: Barbe that's great! Let us know how things go.
Posts.Title: Am I stage II or Stage III jeanjean_chang nelia48

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 06:29AM - edited Apr 7, 2009 06:33AM by Brenda_R Mine was 3.7 cm with clean margins. 0/17 axillary nodes, 1 positive IM node. I am Stage3. It's that IM node that makes you stage 3 and also makes you eligible for SSD.  Even if you are stage 3, that doesn't mean doom. I am 2 years out from dx and doing good. I had A/C chemo x 4, 35 rads with targeted rads to that IM node, and 1 year herceptin.  Since you are ER/PR+ you will also have the option of hormonals.  Keep your chin up. We Stage 3ers do survive.
Posts.Title: Am I stage II or Stage III jeanjean_chang nelia48

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 07:34AM Brenda_R wrote: Barbe, I'm wondering if the IM node they removed was under the breastbone? When I asked my surgeon about removing the positive IM node, he said no, it's almost impossible to get to to remove. Mine was up high about the center of my chest. It showed up on both pet and ct scans.  I didn't have a mastectomy but I think I still would have needed rads to that area to knock out that node. If your node was on top of the bone, and lower down in the chain, you may not need further treatment (?), but I would definately talk to an oncologist.  I take it that you didn't have chemo either?

Posts.Title: Stage 3 and 4 over treated? RANT LittleC lorieg

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2009 12:46AM - edited Nov 10, 2009 12:47AM by Brenda_R I would just tell them that you received the standard care for a person with your stage of BC. I've never once had anyone tell me I was overtreated.  A/C chemo made me so sick that I asked my onc if I could have a lesser dose on my last chemo and he said "well we can only reduce it so much", and instead of 120mg I got 100 that week.  So he was saying in a round about way "we want to make sure you aren't undertreated, and get enough chemo to kill the cancer". Maybe I would just tell someone that said that, "do you want to talk to my onc and see what he says?"
Posts.Title: Stage 3 and 4 over treated? RANT LittleC lorieg

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 02:03AM - edited May 13, 2009 02:10AM by Brenda_R In the year before I found my lump, I was a caregiver to my Mom. She was unable to care for herself and had 2 surgeries and 9 hospitalizations in that year. She was nearly blind (macular degeneration) and could barely walk. She was a very needy person, and I did a 12 hour shift with her daily with very few days off, for months on end. The last month was in the hospital, and the last week was at my sister's where Mom went to pass away. She refused to be in a nursing home. The stress was tremendous.  One month after Mom died, my brother's son died. One month later (over Thanksgiving) I found a lump, and it went from there. So for me, stress played a big part.  I'm one of those that a clear mammo and 6 months later I had a 4 cm lump.  I can't say that stress caused it, but I think the stress, both mental and physical, lowered my immune system and maybe allowed the BC to take off.

Just crazy. You'd think they'd be happy to kick me off, since I have cost them over $200,000 in the last couple years.  I told them, that's fine, I am a cancer patient and I get lots of expensive tests. Lol
Posts.Title: First SSDI, now MEDICARE questions Analemma Sue-61

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 03:03PM Brenda_R wrote: I just switched from hubby's insurance to Medicare. I would have preferred to stay on his plan, but he's been unemployed for about 8 months and we are on "self pay", somewhat similar to Cobra. His insurance paid way better for my scans and meds, but he only has the option to stay on it for 2 more months, then he has no insurance. Meaning I would have none then either if I didn't accept Medicare now.  I could have went on Medicare and stayed on his for those 2 months if we could have afforded it. I can only tell you to make sure that your hubby will have his job for a long, long time, and check your benefits and pay outs now against what Medicare pays.  Where I was paying 0$ for scans, I now have to pay 20%.  Only good part is that labs are at paid at 100%.   If you don't accept Medicare now and want on it later, it will cost you more per month.

Posts.Title: Why do you love and hate the statistics? JudyO PatMom

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 01:42PM Brenda_R wrote: I just bumped the SSD/StageIV thread for you. It has lots of great info. You will need to go to your doctor and tell them you are no longer able to work because of the mets pain/fatigue/etc  and have them write a statement to that effect. When you get that you will need to stop working. I don't think you can get SSD if you are still working.  Apply right away for SSD and tell them you qualify for compassionate allowances fast tracking due to your dx. You will still probably have to go through the 5 month waiting period before you get a check. Then it's 24 more months before you get Medicare.  So you will need to be able to get through the 5 or 6 months it takes to get a check and be able to provide your own insurance for 29 months. It sucks.  I wouldn't even mention school at all. They just want to know if are able to work. You can return to work at any time, and you may or may not lose benefits depending on how much you work.
Posts.Title: Is anybody a full-time student and receives disability? Stefanie LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2010 10:14PM Brenda_R wrote: Lol, well I guess I am somewhat of the opposite. I get ticked off when I read posts saying that chemo is a breeze, and how this or that person worked all through it, and never gave up running, etc.  It used to make me feel like they were trying to make those of us that had a terrible time, feel bad about it. I got over it. Every person is affected differently.  How fit you were going into treatment and your age have quite a bit to do with it.  I was run down, having taken care of a terminally ill, elderly Mom, for the year before I found my lump, and I was 50, out of shape, and stressed to the max. Chemo was very hard on me. I was very sick. Most days my big accomplishment was walking the 20 feet to the bathroom, then back to bed.  I don't begrudge anyone for feeling sick, feeling like they can't cope, or wondering if they can get disability.  Either they can or they can't according to their diagnosis and how they are re-acting to treatment.  A cancer DX is tramatic for anyone.

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2008 07:45AM Brenda_R wrote: Yes, stage 4 should be automatic approval if you have enough working credits. From SSD website- www.ssa.gov/disability/profess...  13.10 Breast (except sarcoma-13.04) (See 13.00K4.) A. Locally advanced carcinoma (inflammatory carcinoma, tumor of any size with direct extension to the chest wall or skin, tumor of any size with metastases to the ipsilateral internal mammary nodes. B. Carcinoma with distant metastases. OR C. Recurrent carcinoma, except local recurrence that remits with antineoplastic therapy. ----------------------------------------------------- D. What evidence do we need? 1. We need medical evidence that specifies the type, extent, and site of the primary, recurrent, or metastatic lesion. When the primary site cannot be identified, we will use evidence documenting the site(s) of metastasis to evaluate the impairment under 13.27. 2. For operative procedures, including a biopsy or a needle aspiration, we generally need a copy of both the: a. Operative note. b. Pathology report. 3. When we cannot get these documents, we will accept the summary of hospitalization(s) or other medical reports. This evidence should include details of the findings at surgery and, whenever appropriate, the pathological findings. 4. In some situations we may also need evidence about recurrence, persistence, or progression of the malignancy, the response to therapy, and any significant residuals. (See 13.00G.) E. When do we need longitudinal evidence? 1. Tumors with distant metastases. We generally do not need longitudinal evidence for tumors that have metastasized beyond the regional lymph nodes because these tumors usually meet the requirements of a listing. Exceptions are for tumors with distant metastases that are expected to respond to antineoplastic therapy. For these exceptions, we usually need a longitudinal record of 3 months after therapy starts to determine whether the intended effect of therapy has been achieved and is likely to persist. 2. Other malignancies. When there are no distant metastases, many of the listings require that we consider your response to initial antineoplastic therapy; that is, the initial planned treatment regimen. This therapy may consist of a single modality or a combination of modalities (multimodal) given in close proximity as a unified whole, and is usually planned before any treatment(s) is initiated. Examples of multimodal therapy include: a. Surgery followed by chemotherapy or radiation. b. Chemotherapy followed by surgery. c. Chemotherapy and concurrent radiation. 3 . Types of treatment. Whenever the initial planned therapy is a single modality, enough time must pass to allow a determination about whether the therapy will achieve its intended effect. If the treatment fails, the failure will often happen within 6 months after treatment starts, and there will often be a change in the treatment regimen. Whenever the initial planned therapy is multimodal, a determination about the effectiveness of the therapy usually cannot be made until the effects of all the planned modalities can be determined. In some cases, we may need to defer adjudication until the effectiveness of therapy can be assessed. However, we do not need to defer adjudication to determine whether the therapy will achieve its intended effect if we can make a fully favorable determination or decision based on the length and effects of therapy, or the residuals of the malignancy or therapy (see 13.00G).  -------------------------------- The thread is here- community.breastcancer.org/for...  I

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2010 12:46PM - edited Sep 2, 2010 01:05PM by Brenda_R I was first dx'ed as Stage IV, and I signed up and was approved for SSD. After 6 months or so, I was re-staged to 3.  I still fit the criteria, as I had a positive IM node that couldn't be removed. It's not as much staging that they look at, but whether you fit the criteria listed of the SSD website, and that you will be unable to work for at least 1 year.  Here's the criteria- 13.10 Breast (except sarcoma-13.04) (See 13.00K4.) A. Locally advanced carcinoma (inflammatory carcinoma, tumor of any size with direct extension to the chest wall or skin, tumor of any size with metastases to the ipsilateral internal mammary nodes. B. Carcinoma with metastases to the supraclavicular or infraclavicular nodes, to 10 or more axillary nodes, or with distant metastases. OR C. Recurrent carcinoma, except local recurrence that remits with antineoplastic therapy   Even if you don't fit those, if you have been unable to work due to medical reasons for over a year and you can get a doctor to write a letter attesting to that, then be sure to appeal your denial!
Posts.Title: Any Stage 3 diagnosis that get Social Security? heatherbless Brenda_R

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 02:38PM Brenda_R wrote: Have you had any scans to see if it is anywhere else?  I'm asking because I had a postive Internal mammary node that couldn't be removed, and having a mastectomy wouldn't have made a difference for me. I still would have had to have chemo and rads for the IM node. You should definately have Herceptin if nothing else. It's a wonder drug for most of us Her2 positives. Her2 + makes us high risk for recurrance and Herceptin knocks that risk down greatly. For most, Herceptin is do-able. Good luck in your decision. Just don't shut out any choices that you won't be able to do later. I would hit it with everything now.

It ended up being 3.7cm with sattelite nodules extending out from it.  I'd had a clear mammo just 6 months prior, and I don't think it was there then.  Nothing could be seen on that mammo, but the it clearly showed on the one done just before biopsy.

Posts.Title: Melitonin roxy42 badboob67

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2009 05:38PM - edited Dec 8, 2009 05:43PM by Brenda_R Yep.   I am also ER- PR- her2 +++ I also had a clear mammo just 6 months earlier.  My tumor was 3.7 cm with 1 positive IM node. Her2 is very aggressive and fast growing, but the Herceptin is a very powerful drug against her2 positive BC. I had a lumpectomy, then the Red Devil (Adriamycin) plus Cytoxin for 3 months, then radiation for 7 weeks, then a year of Herceptin.  I am celebrating 3 years out just this weekend, and am NED (no evidence of disease).  For me, the chemo was very hard to do and I was very sick, but you do get better, it just takes time. A lot depends on your Mom's age.  I wouldn't look too hard at the stats right now, because the ones out there are several years old and don't take into account Herceptin, which is our miracle drug. If , for some reason she can't finish Herceptin, there is still Tykerb and other new drugs coming out for her2 positives.  I don't worry too much about mortality rates.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 07:29AM - edited May 14, 2009 07:31AM by Brenda_R Stage 4 should be automatic, but you need to tell them can no longer do the work. Here's the SSD page for compassionate allowances, that will get you approved quickly- http://www.ssa.gov/compassionateallowances/ You get Medicare after 2 years. You might also want to check out the SSD thread- http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topic/424992?page=20#idx_600
Posts.Title: Social Security/Perm Disability - How do you go about it? JeninMichigan Brenda_R

Posts.Title: H1N1 Poll--ALL STAGES WELCOME! badboob67 wildgardener

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2008 05:22AM Brenda_R wrote: My tumor was located on the inner top side of my right breast.  I would imagine that a left sided tumor is more of a challenge as far as rads, but they will do a CT scan and locate where the heart and lungs lay in proximity, and use that to map out where the rads will be given. They are pretty precise. One thing I would make sure they check, is to see if anything has migrated toward the inner mammary node chain.  Mine spread to my IM node and not toward the axiallary nodes. I wouldn't have known that without a pet/ct scan.
Posts.Title: Tumor Location Jane_M wishiwere

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2008 02:19AM Brenda_R wrote: BMac, at first I was told I was stage IV, due to pet scan. I went for almost 6 months thinking I am stage IV and is the treatment worth the side effects? So I understand thinking the end is near. I was later told (after I asked!) that I was stage III after all. oops... I can't tell you how angry I was and how I now don't trust the doctors to know what's really going on. I can't imagine beating ovarian, and then having to deal with another cancer. But I think once you've been there and beat it once, you know it's possible to do it again.  Hugs to you.

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2009 09:13AM Brenda_R wrote: Bugs, I'm stage 3 and  had a lumpectomy. They gave me a choice, mast and no rads or lump with rads. The way it turned out I would have had to have rads anyway due to positive IM node that was inoperable.   Funny thing was before surgery I had a pet/ct scan and I was dx'ed stage4 with mets to bone. I was still offered a choice. (later found that scan turned out to be false positive)

Posts.Title: 3 year cancerversary today Brenda_R Brenda_R

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 03:05PM - edited Feb 28, 2009 03:06PM by Brenda_R I remember reading in the Social Security Disability thread where a lady called to apply for SSD and the lady taking her call said "people don't DIE from breast cancer!". That one pretty much takes the prize for dumbness. People don't get it because they haven't been in our shoes, or they haven't had a loved one pass from BC. I'm not sure how much education will help. There will always be those that live in la la land. And sometimes those "celebs" that "are cured" of BC actually are a stumbling block to understanding instead of an inspiration. Just my 2 cents.
Posts.Title: Strong Voice roxy42 diana50

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2009 07:44AM - edited Mar 25, 2009 09:21AM by Brenda_R Dear Doctors, I wish that at least one of the 3 of you would have give me the bone scan the pet/ct report suggested as correlation, so I wouldn't have had to go for 6 months thinking I was Stage 4.  One of you even put that "stage 4" in writing. Shame on you.  Even after I asked all 3 of you if I should be getting the bone scan,  you told me no I didn't need it, the pet/ct was enough. It took my first visit with my Rad Onc, to get a bone scan and find out I didn't have bone mets.  To my PCP, I wish you would have taken me seriously when I told you my hips, legs and back hurt badly. Again it took my Rad Onc to order the MRI that showed multi level disc disease, spinal stenosis, and a perineural cyst. Can you also tell a certain nurse that you are the doctor, and you should diagnose me and not her? and you should talk to me about what meds I need and not her?  On the flip side, to my PCP, thank you for being a caring doctor, at least as long as you thought I was stage 4. After you realized I was instead stage 3, it was like a light switch flipped and you no longer had time for me. To my Onc, thank you for writing off the cost of a drug that I couldn't afford. You saved my life.  To my surgeon, thank you for being aggressive in surgery and taking a large portion surrounding my lump. You got clean margins, and that meant a lot to me.  To my Rad Onc, thank you for ordering the scans I needed. Thank you for writing off what the insurance wouldn't pay, so I didn't have to go somewhere else. Thank you for knocking out the cancer in the IM node, that couldn't be removed. I am mad at some of you, but I am also greatful to all of you. I hope you understand.
Posts.Title: Dear doctor, I wish ... mawhinney 2frogs1princess

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2009 10:56AM Brenda_R wrote: I had to put in the 5 month waiting period and did not get retroactive pay. This was because I signed up within 1 month of my dx and we used the dx date as the date of disability. Yeah, the whole waiting period for SSD and Medicare is unfair, imo.  Afaik, it's to save them money.
Posts.Title: Too healthy for disability? donnabee jeanne46

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2009 06:45AM Brenda_R wrote: Quote/ He's proposing Herceptin given concurrently with either Taxotere and Carboplatin or Adriamycin and Cytoxan.  /end quote DON'T let them give Herceptin with Adriamycin! These are never to be given at the same time. They are both cardio toxic. Genentech's own drug fact sheet says NEVER to given Herceptin with Adriamycin.  I know because my onc started me out that way and we had a "discussion" about it. As far as shrinking the tumor, I think that Herceptin alone can also shrink tumors?  It seems that the stage 4 ladies that have had herceptin have had tumors totaly dissapear, if I'm remembering right. But yes, a less toxic chemo may be something she can handle too.

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2009 02:25PM Brenda_R wrote: Thanks for the thanks here too. I don't post here much, but do come to read. I don't always feel that I have much to offer, not going through tx right now, but once in awhile I feel I can add something, just let those of you that are going through it now, that things will get better (although I know it doesn't seem like it). Your life will get back to a new normal. I do empathize with those going through chemo and rads. It hasn't been so long ago that I was too and I remember how I felt.

Posts.Title: Remission & Recurrence StarWish624 JFV

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 03:03AM Brenda_R wrote: Actually Herceptin is very do-able. I had the least effcts from it, although I did have some. Mainly diarhea and runny nose for a day or 2 after treament. I had some hip pain, that I'm pretty sure was from the Herceptin. But it's a miracle drug and if I had the choice to do only 1 thing for BC (being Her2 positive), it would be Herceptin. Good luck to you and your Mom.
Posts.Title: Could Use Some Advice for My Mom Kaliaja Brenda_R

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2009 04:50PM - edited Jun 14, 2009 04:51PM by Brenda_R My onc didn't do chemo for the ladies in their 70's. He said it was just too hard for them.  (I learned this from a couple of older ladies that I had radiation with. We had the same onc.) They did surgery and rads only. I can't speak to the anti hormonals. If it were me, I'd go with surgery, herceptin (if her heart is ok), rads and maybe AI's. I wouldn't do the chemo. I had A/C and it was very hard on me at 50. I can't imagine doing it at 74. Maybe you should get a second opinon from another onc.
Posts.Title: Could Use Some Advice for My Mom Kaliaja Brenda_R
